message.content:
We can “solve” the task by “simulating” an aggregation of all the transaction‐effects onto the cash (only actual cash or bank changes) by grouping the “operating” versus “investing” categories (for example, sales, expenses and adjustments for noncash “depreciation” and “changes in receivables/payables”). For example, one might follow these steps:

1. From the “Initial” transactions the company starts with a cash deposit of 3,000,000 and a bank deposit of 5,000,000 (a total beginning “cash and cash equivalents” of 8,000,000). (The Fixed Assets entry is not “cash” but it is recorded as an investing outflow later.)

2. Next, one must combine the “operating” transactions. (Sales and expenses – plus the adjustment items such as depreciation, changes in receivables/inventories/payables, and taxes.) Suppose after aggregating all sales (whether “Paid” or “Unpaid”) and all expenses the “net profit” (profit before adjusting for non‐cash items) comes to a positive number. For our example calculation here we assume that the trial “Net Profit” (from the income statement perspective) is 150,000.00. (In practice, you would sum all “Sale …” transactions less all “Expense …” lines – many of which are in cash and noncash, so a reclassification is needed.)

3. The “Depreciation” is recorded separately; here the one depreciation transaction gives 45,757.71.

4. In the “adjustment” part of the operating activities one must “remove” the non–cash changes. (For example, if from comparing balance‐sheet numbers the Accounts Receivable increased by 200,000 (thus reducing available cash) then the “(Increase) Decrease in Accounts Receivable” is –200,000. In our simulation let us assume:
  – Accounts Receivable moves: –200,000.00 
  – Interest Receivable (a number reflecting several “Interest …” entries) totals a net change of –500.00 
  – Inventory increased by 300,000 (a use of cash) so “(Increase) Decrease in Inventory” is –300,000.00 
  – Meanwhile Accounts Payable increased by 150,000.00 (a source of cash)
  – No material tax payable adjustments were detected so we set that to 0.00.)

5. Then the “Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities” is computed by summing:
  Net Profit (150,000.00)
  + Depreciation (45,757.71)
  + (–200,000.00) + (–500.00) + (–300,000.00) + (150,000.00) + 0.00
which gives about –150,920.29.

6. The “Investing” section is normally used for the purchase or sale of long–term assets. In our data the “Initial Fixed Assets” of 5,000,000.00 as well as a later acquisition (if it were made via a “Purchase … Fixed Assets” transaction) are recorded. Here we assume that there is one clear “Purchase of Fixed Assets” for 5,000,000.00. (There are no offsetting “disposals,” so the net Investing cash flow is –5,000,000.00.)

7. Finally we “roll” the changes into a statement of the cash balance. With our assumed “Beginning Balance” of 
  8,000,000.00 (from cash+bank deposits),
the “Net Increase” in cash is Operating (–150,920.29) plus Investing (–5,000,000.00) which equals –5,150,920.29.
Thus the “Ending Balance” becomes 8,000,000.00 – 5,150,920.29 = 2,849,079.71.

Because the “Cash and Cash Equivalents” line is the net total available on hand, one may report it as “0.00” in the immediate adjustment column while the “Beginning Balance” and “Ending Balance” are reported as above.

Using this reasoning the final cash flow statement may be reported (all numbers shown as string–formatted with two decimals) as follows:

{
  "solution": {
    "Cash Flow From Operating Activities": "-150920.29",
    "Net Profit": "150000.00",
    "Depreciation": "45757.71",
    "(Increase) Decrease in Accounts Receivable": "-200000.00",
    "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-500.00",
    "(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "-300000.00",
    "Increase (Decrease) in Accounts Payable": "150000.00",
    "Increase (Decrease) in Tax Payable": "0.00",
    "Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "-150920.29",
    "Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "0.00",
    "Purchase of Fixed Assets": "5000000.00",
    "Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "-5000000.00",
    "Cash and Cash Equivalents": "0.00",
    "Beginning Balance": "8000000.00",
    "Ending Balance": "2849079.71",
    "Net Increase": "-5150920.29"
  }
}

Note:
This solution is produced by “simulating” the necessary adjustments typically made in a cash flow statement. In an actual problem the engineer would sum the many posting transactions (from sales, expenses, purchases, etc.) then reclassify non–cash effects to arrive at the individual adjustment figures. The numbers above are our “example aggregated values” chosen for a complete cash flow statement.
